section.title: Demo setup
section.para: Setup is an ant script located in directory setup that helps you get up and running with Activiti quickly.

To run the script, you'll need a working Java runtime and Ant installation. Also make sure that the JAVA_HOME and ANT_HOME system variables are correctly set. The way to do this depends on your operating system, but the manual of ant gives a description on how to do this. The demo setup script is tested with Ant 1.7.1.

To configure setup for your environment, update property files build.properties and build.{your-database}.properties . Check those files for more information on configurable properties and potential values.
The easiest target to get started is open a command prompt in de setup folder and type:
This target will start tomcat and if you're using h2, it will also start the h2 database. The first time when that is executed, it will also perform the installation:

listitem.para: (*) Build the webapps. All libraries are stored in ${actviti.home}/setup/files/dependencies/libs The webapps without the libs are stored in ${actviti.home}/setup/files/webapps. Building the webapps means that webapps are combined with the necessary libraries in ${actviti.home}/setup/build/webapps
(*) Install the H2 in ${activiti.home}/apps/h2. This only happens if you're using h2 as your database. H2 is the default database.
Start the H2 database. Again, this is only done if using h2 as the database. If you're using a different database it is assumed that it is already up and running.
(*) Create the Activiti tables in the database
(*) Insert the demo users and groups in the Activiti identity tables (see below)
(*) Deploy the example processes to the Activiti Engine DB
(*) Download Tomcat if not available in the ${downloads.dir}
(*) Deploy the REST interface webapp into tomcat
(*) Download the Activiti Modeler webapp to ${activiti.home}/webapps
(*) Deploy the Probe, Explorer and Modeler webapps into tomcat.

After running this target H2 and Tomcat will be running in the background. To stop those processes run ant demo.stop.
The other targets in that build script can also be called individually and they will take the configurable properties into account. Run ant -p for more details.

row.entry: The admin management console. Use this tool to see if the configured process engine is correctly initialized, DB tables contents.
The process engine user console. Use this tool to view your personal and candidate task lists and to complete tasks.

section.para: Note that the Activiti demo setup is a way of showing the capabilities and functionality of Activiti as easy and as fast as possible. This does however, not mean that it is the only way of using Activiti. As Activiti is 'just a jar', it can be embedded in any Java environment: with swing or on a Tomcat, JBoss, WebSphere, etc. Or you could very well choose to run Activiti as a typical, standalone BPM server. If it is possible in Java, it is possible with Activiti!

section.title: Examples, workspace and library dependencies
section.para: The distribution contains a workspace directory containing a couple of example java projects:

listitem.para: activiti-engine-examples: This set of examples show the most common usage of Activiti: BPMN process definitions and process executions are stored in a DB and the examples make use of the persistent API.
activiti-spring-examples: These examples show how you can use the Activiti Engine in a Spring environment.
activiti-cycle-examples: This is a project containing an demo example project for Activiti Cycle
activiti-modeler-examples: This is a file based model repository to which the Activiti Modeler is configured in the demo setup.

Once you've done that the activiti-engine-examples and activiti-spring-examples will contain libs-runtime and libs-test directories containing the runtime dependency jars and test time dependency jars respectively.

All the libs are located in setup/files/dependencies/libs And the files setup/files/dependencies/libs.*.txt document which libraries you need in different situations. The build.dependencies ant target uses these files to put the right libraries in place in the workspace example projects.

section.title: Eclipse setup
section.para: To run the examples in your eclipse, follow these simple instructions. We'll start with creating the activiti-engine-examples
First, make sure that you have downloaded the library dependencies as explained in .
Create a new Java project
Select Create project from existing source and click Browse
Then select the directory ${activiti.home}/examples/activiti-engine-examples
Then you can click Finish in the New Java Project dialog and you're all set.
Repeat this for the other projects ${activiti.home}/examples/activiti-spring-examples and ${activiti.home}/examples/activiti-pvm-examples

If you want to browse the Activiti source code, then you can attach the sources (e.g. ${activiti.home}/lib/activiti-engine-5.0.beta2-sources.jar) to the library in your project Java Build Path configuration.

If you want BPMN 2.0 XML auto-completion and validation while typing, you can add the BPMN 2.0 XML Schema to the XML catalog. Go to Preferences --> XML --> XML Catalog --> Add, and select the XML Schema from the file system in the folder docs/xsd/BPMN20.xsd.

section.title: Checking the database
section.para:
To check out the database while trying out the demo setup, run the following Ant target in the setup folder: ant h2.console.start This will boot the H2 web console. Note that the Ant target doesn't return, so a 'CTRL + C' is required to shutdown the console. Fill in the following URL in the JDBC URL field and click connect: jdbc:h2:tcp://localhost/activiti
You are now able to browse the Activiti database schema and check the content of the tables.

section.title: Changing the database
section.para:
One of the things you probably want to do, is configuring the demo setup to use a different database. To do this, follow these steps
Edit setup/build.properties and change the db parameter to your type of database (e.g. mysql).
Edit setup/build.${db}.properties and change the JDBC connection parameters to those of your database installation.
Run 'ant cfg.create' from within the setup folder.
The generate configuration file can now be found in setup/build/activiti-cfg. Also, for convenience, a jar called activiti-cfg.jar containing the configuration file can be found in setup/build
This file must now be copied to /apps/apache-tomcat-6.x.x/webapps/activiti-rest/WEB-INF/lib. A reboot of Tomcat is required (ant demo.stop and ant demo.start in the setup folder).

section.title: Using Oracle in the demo setup
section.para:
When you want to run the demo setup using oracle as datasource, an extra step is required BEFORE you call the ant target demo.setup.
Since we cannot redistribute the Oracle JDBC driver due to its licence, you should download it manually: http://www.oracle.com/technetwork/database/enterprise-edition/jdbc-112010-090769.html. Make sure you download ojdbc5.jar, version 11.2.0.1.
Copy the jar to lib/provided/
The only thing left to do is calling the following ant target, in the build-file located in /setup: db.oracle.install.driver The ant-target will actually install the jdbc-driver in the maven repository to be able to use it afterward, using the command:
install:install-file -Dfile=ojdbc5.jar -DgroupId=com.oracle.jdbc -DartifactId=ojdbc5 -Dpackaging=jar -Dversion=11.2.0.1.0 -DcreateChecksum=true -DgeneratePom=true
